palette.tooltip: A radio button is a two-states button that can be either checked or unchecked.

palette.title: CheckBox
palette.tooltip: A checkbox is a specific type of two-states button that can be either checked or unchecked.

palette.title: ToggleButton
palette.tooltip: Displays checked/unchecked states as a button with a 'light' indicator and by default accompanied with the text 'ON' or 'OFF'.

palette.title: CheckedTextView
palette.tooltip: An extension to TextView that supports the Checkable interface.

palette.title: EditText
palette.tooltip: EditText is a thin veneer over TextView that configures itself to be editable.

palette.title: AutoCompleteTextView
palette.tooltip: An editable text view that shows completion suggestions automatically while the user is typing.

palette.tooltip: An editable text view, extending AutoCompleteTextView, that can show completion suggestions for the substring of the text where the user is typing instead of necessarily for the entire thing.

palette.title: ExtractEditText
palette.tooltip: Specialization of EditText for showing and interacting with the extracted text in a full-screen input method.

palette.title: AnalogClock
palette.tooltip: This widget displays an analog clock with two hands for hours and minutes.

palette.title: TextClock
palette.tooltip: This widget displays the current date and/or time as a formatted string

palette.title: DigitalClock
palette.tooltip: Like AnalogClock, but digital. Shows seconds.

palette.title: Chronometer
palette.tooltip: Class that implements a simple timer.

palette.title: SurfaceView
palette.tooltip: Provides a dedicated drawing surface embedded inside of a view hierarchy. You can control the format of this surface and, if you like, its size; the SurfaceView takes care of placing the surface at the correct location on the screen.

palette.title: TextureView
palette.tooltip: A TextureView can be used to display a content stream. Such a content stream can for instance be a video or an OpenGL scene.

palette.title: VideoView
palette.tooltip: Displays a video file. The VideoView class can load images from various sources (such as resources or content providers), takes care of computing its measurement from the video so that it can be used in any layout manager, and provides various display options such as scaling and tinting.

palette.title: ProgressBar
palette.tooltip: Visual indicator of progress in some operation.

palette.title: SeekBar
palette.tooltip: A SeekBar is an extension of ProgressBar that adds a draggable thumb.

palette.title: RatingBar
palette.tooltip: A RatingBar is an extension of SeekBar and ProgressBar that shows a rating in stars.

palette.title: ImageView
palette.tooltip: Displays an arbitrary image, such as an icon.

palette.title: ImageButton
palette.tooltip: Displays a button with an image (instead of text) that can be pressed or clicked by the user.

palette.tooltip: Widget used to show an image with the standard QuickContact badge and on-click behavior.

palette.title: Space
palette.tooltip: Space is a lightweight View subclass that may be used to create gaps between components in general purpose layouts.

palette.title: KeyboardView
palette.tooltip: A view that renders a virtual Keyboard. It handles rendering of keys and detecting key presses and touch movements.

palette.title: GestureOverlayView
palette.tooltip: A transparent overlay for gesture input that can be placed on top of other widgets or contain other widgets.

palette.title: ViewStub
palette.tooltip: A ViewStub is an invisible, zero-sized View that can be used to lazily inflate layout resources at runtime.

palette.title: DatePicker
palette.tooltip: This class is a widget for selecting a date.

palette.title: TimePicker
palette.tooltip: A view for selecting the time of day, in either 24 hour or AM/PM mode.

palette.title: NumberPicker
palette.tooltip: A widget that enables the user to select a number form a predefined range. The widget presents an input field and up and down buttons for selecting the current value. Pressing/long-pressing the up and down buttons increments and decrements the current value respectively.

palette.title: ZoomControls
palette.tooltip: The ZoomControls class displays a simple set of controls used for zooming and provides callbacks to register for events.

palette.title: SearchView
palette.tooltip: A widget that provides a user interface for the user to enter a search query and submit a request to a search provider. Shows a list of query suggestions or results, if available, and allows the user to pick a suggestion or result to launch into.

palette.title: ListView
palette.tooltip: A view that shows items in a vertically scrolling list. The items come from the ListAdapter associated with this view.

palette.title: ExpandableListView
palette.tooltip: A view that shows items in a vertically scrolling two-level list. This differs from the ListView by allowing two levels: groups which can individually be expanded to show its children.

palette.title: GridView
palette.tooltip: A view that shows items in two-dimensional scrolling grid. The items in the grid come from the ListAdapter associated with this view.

palette.title: WebView
palette.tooltip: A View that displays web pages. This class is the basis upon which you can roll your own web browser or simply display some online content within your Activity.

palette.title: ScrollView
palette.tooltip: Layout container for a view hierarchy that can be scrolled by the user, allowing it to be larger than the physical display. ScrollView only supports vertical scrolling.

palette.title: HorizontalScrollView
palette.tooltip: Layout container for a view hierarchy that can be scrolled by the user, allowing it to be larger than the physical display.

palette.title: Spinner
palette.tooltip: A view that displays one child at a time and lets the user pick among them.

palette.title: MediaController
palette.tooltip: A view containing controls for a MediaPlayer. Typically contains the buttons like 'Play/Pause', 'Rewind', 'Fast Forward' and a progress slider. It takes care of synchronizing the controls with the state of the MediaPlayer.

palette.title: StackView
palette.tooltip: A view that displays its children in a stack and allows users to discretely swipe through the children.

palette.title: AdapterViewFlipper
palette.tooltip: Simple ViewAnimator that will animate between two or more views that have been added to it. Only one child is shown at a time. If requested, can automatically flip between each child at a regular interval.

palette.title: ViewAnimator
palette.tooltip: Container that will perform animations when switching between its views.

palette.title: ViewFlipper
palette.tooltip: Simple ViewAnimator that will animate between two or more views that have been added to it. Only one child is shown at a time. If requested, can automatically flip between each child at a regular interval.

palette.title: ViewSwitcher
palette.tooltip: ViewAnimator that switches between two views, and has a factory from which these views are created. You can either use the factory to create the views, or add them yourself. A ViewSwitcher can only have two child views, of which only one is shown at a time.

palette.title: TextSwitcher
palette.tooltip: Specialized ViewSwitcher that contains only children of type TextView. A TextSwitcher is useful to animate a label on screen.

palette.title: RadioGroup
palette.tooltip: This class is used to create a multiple-exclusion scope for a set of radio buttons. Checking one radio button that belongs to a radio group unchecks any previously checked radio button within the same group.

palette.title: TabHost
palette.tooltip: Container for a tabbed window view. This object holds two children: a set of tab labels that the user clicks to select a specific tab, and a FrameLayout object that displays the contents of that page. The individual elements are typically controlled using this container object, rather than setting values on the child elements themselves.

palette.title: LinearLayout
palette.tooltip: A Layout that arranges its children in a single row or column.

palette.title: FrameLayout
palette.tooltip: FrameLayout is designed to block out an area on the screen to display a single item.

palette.title: CoordinatorLayout
palette.tooltip: CoordinatorLayout is a super-powered FrameLayout.

palette.title: CollapsingToolbarLayout
palette.tooltip: CollapsingToolbarLayout is a special purpose layout.

palette.title: AppBarLayout
palette.tooltip: AppBarLayout is a super-powered FrameLayout.

palette.title: AbsoluteLayout
palette.tooltip: A layout that lets you specify exact locations (x/y coordinates) of its children. Absolute layouts are less flexible and harder to maintain than other types of layouts without absolute positioning.

palette.title: TableLayout
palette.tooltip: A layout that arranges its children into rows and columns. A TableLayout consists of a number of TableRow objects, each defining a row (actually, you can have other children, which will be explained below). TableLayout containers do not display border lines for their rows, columns, or cells. Each row has zero or more cells; each cell can hold one View object. The table has as many columns as the row with the most cells. A table can leave cells empty. Cells can span columns, as they can in HTML.

palette.title: TableRow
palette.tooltip: A layout that arranges its children horizontally. A TableRow should always be used as a child of a TableLayout. If a TableRow's parent is not a TableLayout, the TableRow will behave as an horizontal LinearLayout.

palette.title: GridLayout
palette.tooltip: A layout that places its children in a rectangular grid.

palette.title: v7.GridLayout
palette.tooltip: A layout that places its children in a rectangular grid.

palette.title: RelativeLayout
palette.tooltip: A Layout where the positions of the children can be described in relation to each other or to the parent.
